 axaml:
NumericUpDown ValueChanged="NumericUpDown_ValueChanged" Value="{Binding SetPointNumber, Mode=TwoWay}"  

"NumericUpDown_ValueChanged" is excuted before SetPointNumber set  when SetPointNumber value changes

### To Reproduce

Bind a property, register an event, change the value

11.10

Windows

_No response_
author: highstars-gxx

comments.body: The ValueChanged event is the Value stored in the control, and no assumptions can be made about the existence of a binding to Value at all.  I don't think there's a practical way to defer the event firing until after Bindings have updated given that in practice the Control is completely unaware they exist, and that quite possibly the Bindings themselves are using the event to do their work.
Why can the TextChanged event of Textbox be used? Can you refer to it and make some adjustments? I would appreciate any help.
@highstars-gxx can you please explain what exactly you want to achieve? It's hard for me to understand where the bug should be tbh

I want to implement a function to divide numbers evenly, and divide them evenly automatically as the number of points changes.So I bind a denominator(SetPointNumber) and an average function("NumericUpDown_ValueChanged") to automatically average when the denominator changes.But the average result each time is the value of the previous time.
This is imo a task for your ViewModel. This can calculate and update the value as needed.
It's ValueChanged, not ValueChanging or before changed.So I think it would be better if the value is updated before the event is triggered.
I still don't get it tbh. Please file a very minimal sample for me to understand what the issue is.

> It's ValueChanged, not ValueChanging or before changed.So I think it would be better if the value is updated before the event is triggered.

The Value has changed.  The Value property on the NumericUpDown.  SetPointNumber hasn't been updated yet because it responds to the same event you do, ValueChanged.

@highstars-gxx I really think you want to handle new numbers either only in your ViewModel or in the ValueChanged event but then by using the event args. 

I also honestly don't see a bug here, so will close this as by design until we get a minimum sample to reproduce.

title: Resizeable and Collapsable sidebar with GridSplitter
body:
Hi!
I'm trying to make a resizeable and collapsable sidebar. 

I expect it to have the following behaviour:

1. A user can resize the sidebar up and down to a particular boundary (i.e. set Min and Max width).
2. A user can entirely hide (and then show) the sidebar

I use Grid with three columns: one for the sidebar, the second for the GridSplitter to accomplish resize and the third for the main content.

If I configure the Grid like this:

```XAML
<Grid.ColumnDefinitions>
    <ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" />
    <ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" />
    <ColumnDefinition Width="*" />
</Grid.ColumnDefinitions>
```

I can successfully resize the sidebar and hide it with `IsVisible="True"` but it does not have Min Width. If I set MinWidth for the sidebar control
```XAML
<Panel Grid.Column="0" MinWidth="100" />
```
I can still resize the leftmost column to the size less than it's content MinWidth. 

If I set MinWidth for a Grid Column:
```XAML
<ColumnDefinition Width="Auto" MinWidth="100" />
```
The splitter lets me resize the column down to this MinWidth (just like I need), however, when I hide the sidebar with `IsVisible="False"` the column persists (i.e. blank space with MinWidth is shown).

The splitter is very thin and it is not an option to resize the column to width 0 and consider this as "collapsed" since there is no way to resize it back.

I'm using Avalonia 0.10.0-rc1
author: unconverged

comments.body: Hi there! I'm just experiencing this same behavior right now. Is there a way to hide a resized column in a grid?

There is an expected behavior with the grid. Column can not hidden, if you set MinWidth to it. You need to set it to zero. 
Alternatively you can set MinWidth on the child control itself.
SplitView has similar behavior out of box, but without grid splitter
You can Add a Thumb to the GridSplitter which you can use to Resize the Pane.

> You can Add a Thumb to the GridSplitter which you can use to Resize the Pane.

Сan you please give an example ?

I solved that issue by applying one of two classes that change the `Grid.ColumnSpan` attribute and toggling visibility of GridSplitter and Sidebar container:


```xml
<Panel>
  <Panel.Styles>
    <Style Selector=".sidebar_open">
      <Setter Property="Grid.ColumnSpan" Value="1"></Setter>
    </Style>
    <Style Selector=".sidebar_close">
      <Setter Property="Grid.ColumnSpan" Value="3"></Setter>
    </Style>
  </Panel.Styles>

  <Grid ColumnDefinitions="*,Auto, 420">
    <Panel Grid.Column="0"
      Classes.sidebar_open="{Binding IsSidebarOpen}"
      Classes.sidebar_close="{Binding !IsSidebarOpen}">
    </Panel>
    <GridSplitter Grid.Column="1" Width="3" MinWidth="1" BorderThickness="0"
      VerticalAlignment="Stretch"
      IsVisible="{Binding IsSidebarOpen}"></GridSplitter>
    <Panel Grid.Column="1" IsVisible="{Binding IsSidebarOpen}">
      <TextBlock>This is the sidebar</TextBlock>
    </Panel>
  </Grid>
  
</Panel>

```

comments.body:
@SCLD-JBuczkowski Avalonia includes ReactiveUI for convenience, however you are free to simply implement `INotifyPropertyChanged` on your viewmodel classes, or use another framework that does this for you.

    We recommend ReactiveUI because it removes the need for a lot of boilerplate code needed to get started with Avalonia, WPF, UWP, Xamarin and other similar frameworks.
V11 no longer ships with RX dependencies. We've also updated our docs to make it clearer that RxUI isn't a requirement.

title: ComboBox.SelectedItem only returns the typename and not the selected Value When using a Datatemplate
body:
I have a combobox configured like so

```
      <ComboBox SelectedItem="{Binding SelectedModule, Mode=OneWayToSource}" Grid.Column="0" BorderBrush="Black" Grid.Row="2" Height="25" Margin="5" Items="{Binding SubCommands}">
        <ComboBox.ItemTemplate>
          <DataTemplate>
            <TextBlock Text="{Binding DisplayName}" ToolTip.Tip="{Binding Description}"/>
          </DataTemplate>
        </ComboBox.ItemTemplate>
      </ComboBox>
```
And the viewmodel is 
```
        public string SelectedModule
        {
            get => selectedModule;
            private set
            {
                var res = value;
                this.RaiseAndSetIfChanged(ref selectedModule, value);
            }
        }
```
I am getting back the typename of the Items property instead of the value of the textblock text. How can I get that WPF mentions DisplayMemberName but that doesn't seem to exist in Avalonia.

I also tried 
`SelectionBoxItem="{Binding SelectedModule, Mode=OneWayToSource}" `
but that didn't work either
author: ajmcateer

comments.body: This is the expected behavior and matches what the Wpf version does. As you noted we are missing the DisplayMemberPath feature and the SelectedValue property. This needs to be added. For now you could use a converter.
How is `SubCommands` defined in the view model?

Thanks... Now I'm a bit confused ;)

When you say:

> I am getting back the typename of the Items property instead of the value of the textblock text. 

What do you mean by "I'm getting back"? You mean the type name is assigned to `SelectedModule`? `SelectedModule` is a `string` so Avalonia is having to somehow convert `SubCommandModel` to a string, for which it uses `ToString()`. If you've not overridden `ToString`, then it will just return the name of the type, which is what you're seeing.

Are you porting WPF code which uses `DisplayMemberName`? As you've seen we don't have this property in Avalonia, so a direct port isn't going to be possible. Or are you writing new code?

Can you not just change `public string SelectedModule` to `public SubCommandModel SelectedModule` in your view model?
@grokys Thank you, I did not realize it was just calling ToString() on subcommand module, it makes a lot of sense in hindsight. I did just as you suggested and it works great.

title: Gauging interest: MayExecute for commands
author: bhood-zorus

comments.body: It's quite interesting! I can definitely see the use-case of that interface in LoB apps (especially permissions and stuff like that).
Sound interesting. In your apps where you use this, do you tend to jave different logic for can execute and may execute?
I really like this.
Sounds like a pretty positive reception so far 🙂 I'll start working on a branch tonight.

From what I understand, this is essentially to allow changing the visibility state as well as the enabled state from a command?

I have needed to do that a few times myself, but usually I've found one of the following strategies works:

- Often I want to hide e.g. the button when the bound command is `CanExecute() == false`. This can be done pretty easily using styles in Avalonia, e.g. `<Style Selector="Button.autohide:disabled><Setter Property="IsVisible" Value="False"/></Style>`
- If I want a three-state visible/disabled/hidden button, then I can set the command to null in the view model, and bound the `IsVisible` property to make the button only visible when the command is non-null, e.g. `<Button IsVisible="{Binding !!MyCommand}>`.

Do the techniques above not address your use-cases?

I wouldn't be adverse to adding e.g. a `ICommandEx` interface with a `ShouldShow` property on it (which is what I think you're suggesting, but with different naming), but I'd have a few reservations:

- I usually use ReactiveUI's `ReactiveCommand` rather than rolling my own `ICommand` implementation. This wouldn't know anything about this new interface, meaning I'd have to roll my own `ICommand` implementation. That would probably mean that I personally wouldn't really use it.
- Your description of the problem sounds very focused on your business logic. Does it really need to be part of the framework? Remember that once you add a feature, even if it's used by a _tiny_ minority, it's very hard to take it away without making people angry!
- What other state could/should be put into this new interface? For example I often want to change the caption on the button depending on logic in the view model. Should we but a `Caption` property on this new interface? If so where do we stop? What is the boundary between framework and business logic?

There's also of course naming: `MayExecute` vs `CanExecute` isn't really very descriptive, which is why I suggested `ShouldSHow` but we can bikeshed that when we decide it's needed ;)

@grokys 
> just using CanExecute

This ignores the purpose of the proposal. `MayExecute` offers a separation of concerns.

> binding to !!MyCommand

That's a cool trick. Given the first two of the three bullet points underneath, it could be totally sufficient; it also looks more idiomatic.

BTW, I happen to think `May` vs `Can` is perfectly descriptive. Just because you can do something doesn't mean you're actually allowed to do it.

title: The way we should load custom fonts
body:
#### WPF approach:

Specify font family with `pack://application:,,,/fonts/#MySuperFont Bold` (`res://AssemlyName.dll/fonts/#MySuperFont` or `res:/fonts/#MySuperFont` in our case)
Upsides:
- really easy to isolate fonts between assemblies
- auto-discovery of font variants (italic, bold)
Downsides:
- verbose
- fonts might get duplicated
- we need to migrate to WPF's model of handling resources that preserves actual file paths in the project. That will require an MSBuild task and runtime support in our asset loader. We need to completely migrate from `resm`, because relative uris won't work otherwise. That will *break* existing applications.

#### CSS approach

Register fonts globally somewhere. CSS does it like that:
```
 @font-face {
    font-family: myFirstFont;
    src: url(sansation_bold.woff);
    font-weight: bold;
    font-style: italic;
}
```

In our cast that would be:
```xml
<Application.Fonts>
  <FontResource FontFamily="MyFont" Uri="resm:Fonts.myfont.ttf" FontWeight="Normal" FontStyle="Italic"/>
</Application.Fonts>
```

Upsides:
- It would be possible to write `<TextBlock FontFamily="MyFont">` and it will just work

Downsides:
- It's needed to manually specify ttf file for each font variant (bold, italic)
- It won't be possible to have assembly-local fonts that don't interfere with anything else
- It would be troublesome to register fonts from component assemblies


@grokys @danwalmsley @jkoritzinsky @wieslawsoltes
author: kekekeks

comments.body:
About fonts duplicating / interfering, as part of this we should allow comma separated font family names, where it searches maybe: Local assembly, then resources, then system fonts. 

The issues with css method like trouble registering from component assembly, we are able tondo this with styles already so this could be overcome? Font variants perhaps we can have a syntax to specify multiple ttf files?

I like the WPF way, even if just for the relative paths for resources.

Also, couldn't we get syntax similar to the pro in the CSS section while still using the WPF-style loading?
As a temporary measure we could use `zip` files embedded as resources and treat them as "font collections".
The real question here is whether we want to switch to path-preserving resource model or not.

> we need to migrate to WPF's model of handling resources that preserves actual file paths in the project. 

What prevents loading fonts via the existing `resm:` scheme?

> We need to completely migrate from resm, because relative uris won't work otherwise. That will break existing applications.

You mean that support for `resm:` resources would have to be removed? Why is that?

>What prevents loading fonts via the existing resm: scheme?

Fonts consist of several `ttf` files. Some of them contain only one font variant, some contain multiple. WPF handles that by accepting a *directory* path and a font name, then it scans all font files in said resource directory and constructs a collection of typefaces for that font. We can't do that with `resm`, because directory separator char becomes dot (`.`) and we can't distinguish between them at run time.

>You mean that support for resm: resources would have to be removed? Why is that?

Relative paths won't work between `res` and `resm` schemes, that will generate a lot of confusion. `resm` scheme was a workaround for Mono not having proper build targets, if I remember correctly. We were planning to implement our own build task later, but had never done so.

Another option that won't require us to have path-preserving resource system is globbing. 
E. g. 
```xml
<TextBlock FontFamily="resm:Some.Namespace.myfont*.ttf#MySuperFont">
```
For relative paths between `resm` and `res`, we could standardize on `resm` always being in the root directory.

> resm scheme was a workaround for Mono not having proper build targets, if I remember correctly

I don't think so - if I remember correctly it was because mono didn't have support for WPF-style resources (reading or writing)

>mono didn't have support for WPF-style resources 

Mono can read them without any issues, but xbuild/msbuild-on-mono doesn't have the required build targets for generating them.
Now that #1564 is merged I'm going to mark this as fixed.

title: Bitmap disposal
body:
Since bitmaps typically consume tons of memory, it's worth to have an option to explicitly dispose them. However, if bitmap is already used somewhere, application will just crash, and that's not what we want.

So the proposal is to have a static instance of transparent 1x1 bitmap, which will be used as a substitute for `BitmapImpl` in `Bitmap` class. It should be provided by rendering subsystem and never get disposed. That way we won't need complex checks in our rendering code to determine if we can use bitmap or not.

title: New live previewer architecture + Avalonia.Remote proposal
body:
Since we need to run user's code anyway (for custom controls, design-time mock data, etc), previewer will stay out of process. The main issue with the current one is that it's not portable and causes issues with build in visual studio.

Portability issues come from the fact that previewer uses  some kind of reflection and win32 api voodoo to do the following:
1) Load every assembly from build output directory
2) Initialize it with "proper" windowing subsystem
3) Initialize subsystem-specific hacks
4) Pass created window handle to parent process via stdout, so it could be reparented via Win32 API.

That obviously won't work properly with .NET Core and other platforms. It also all happens in a separate executable file, which has to be shipped with VS Extension.


----------------------


So, the new previewer implementation should live in Avalonia itself.
It would be initialized using appbuilder, something like:


```cs
AppBuilder.Configure<App>()
    .UseRemotePreviewer() // <-------
    .UsePlatformDetect()
    .Start<MainWindow>();
```

`UseRemotePreviewer` should analyze environment variables and/or command line arguments to see if it's being run by some kind of IDE. In this case it should attempt to connect to IDE host using provided method.
Command line will look somewhat like:
`--avalonia-start-previewer --avalonia-previewer-transport=tcp://127.0.0.1:15543`

Once connection is established, it will start sending log messages to the host.

It will next setup an offscreen windowing platform emulation and configure compatible rendering engine (for now Skia, since it already can render directly to a byte array), then *bypass further AppBuilder configuration options completely* and straight up call `SetupWithoutStarting`, followed by entering host's command handling mode.

Communication should be done using BSON messages. Host will send XAML updates, input events, scaling options changes and receive back framebuffer updates.

That makes previewer completely platform-agnostic, since you can just run compiled application with some command line options.

----------------------

Base support for remote widgets is worth of having a support that's completely separate from designer, since it potentially provides a lot of value by itself. For example, we could run our devtools directly on Android/iOS and then connect to them via TCP.

DTO (data transfer objects) and Stream-based  for remote widget communications shall live in a separate library `Avalonia.Remote.Protocol` available via NuGet (might be worth including previewer-specific messages in the same library). It will be considered to be a protocol spec, since it directly maps to JSON objects. Each DTO should have a GUID. It should be possible to pass custom messages or substitute transport completely, because it may be required for end-user's application. 

Widget hosting and offscreen platform implementations should live in the main repo/library, since they are coupled to platform interfaces.

We should also provide Avalonia and WPF controls for rendering remote widgets, so it would be easy to use from VS extension and AvalonStudio.
author: kekekeks

comments.body:
Roadmap:
- [x] Allow to create bitmap directly from memory, since PNG encoding actually takes some time and it's way cheaper to just transfer a huge blob via IPC or local wifi (pull #903)
- [x] Allow bitmaps to be disposed (issue #904, not exactly necessary with `WritableBitmap`)
- [x] Design `Avalonia.Remote.Protocol` and create a basic implementation over TCP + BSON
- [x] Create `OffscreenTopLevelImpl : ITopLevelImpl` that has it's own framebuffer (might also be very useful for embedded devices since they will want double-buffering anyway).
- [x] Create wire up offscreeen toplevel with protocol implementation, implement `RemoteConrol` for Avalonia
- [ ] Create offscreen toplevel for WPF.
- [ ] Do `UseRemotePreviewer` voodoo
- [ ] Implement support for remote devtools

Why not make some protocol for sending input events and getting back delta-XAML?

Bitmaps may need to be rendered at client bitdepth etc on the server to be efficient, but don't see how sending uncompressed bitmaps is scalable if used with multiple clients or with fast updates (say video / animated images)
The whole point of the protocol is to embed widget into something that **can't** dipslay our XAML in it's own process.
What's left to do in this issue since #1105 was merged in? Should we spin those items out into different, more specific issues now that the remoting infra and new previewer are merged in?
Input events aren't implemented yet
